evidence.text: Person A: Oh, we chatted at Mommy Baby Yoga! Just for a sec though. Jen. So do you paint...or something else?

Person B: Kefir. Homemade- with chia seeds and cardamom. Do you want one for your son?
Person A: Oh that’s ok. I gotta get him home for his nap.
Person A: Please don’t have a tantrum, please don’t have a tantrum.
Person A: Construction site. Turn out the light. Great work today and now goodnight.

Person A: Well, look what the cat dragged in!
Person B: He’s a dog today.

Person A: Oh I don’t really hike.
Person A: Sounds awful.

Person B: Strawberry shampoo.
Person B: Sorry. My sense of smell is so strong right now.
Person B: Oh my god yes. My husband says the same thing. That the sounds coming out of me were pure animal. He almost passed out. But he’s not good with blood.

Person A: A wild animal?
Person A: Do you ever feel like the big secret is that we are gods?
Person B: Jen! Wow - hi. It’s weird to see you in the wild - out of context.

Person A: I’ve been thinking about that conversation in the library non- stop.
Person A: Yes. That thing you said about how mothers are mocked in popular culture -

Person B: Are you coming to baby yoga or tyke hike this week?
Person B: Oh poo. Next time. Come on, kiddos! Let’s go see the dinosaur bones!

Person B: So what did you do before you had your kids?
Person A: Yeah. Worked 80 hour weeks. I made more money than my husband - I like to remind him of that sometimes. It was too intense though- emails at 2 am, working dinners. The corporate world does not respect mothers. It’s not the life for having littles.
Person B: How do you like staying home? You seem really good at it. It’s totally intimidating.
Person B: I thought I would like being a stay at home mom. But it’s just not been good for me.
Person A: You’re allowed to change your mind.
Person B: Can I admit something terrible? I fantasize about running away from it all sometimes. I dream about a faded beach chair and a good book and not talking to anyone for a week.
Person A: That’s not terrible at all. Once when I really needed a break I told my husband that I had diarrhea and I locked myself in the bathroom and read magazines in a bubble bath for hours. And I was so fucking happy.
Person B: Well... I guess I’ve kind of hit a breaking point. My husband and I are getting a separation and I killed our cat this week, and it just made me realize I’m not doing so great. Emotionally.
Person A: But what happened with your husband?
Person B: He wasn’t around that much before. It doesn’t feel much different.
